metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Appellants filed suit for declaration that they were citizens of India and for injunction restraining defendants from removing them from India.
Appellants stated they were citizens of India and had not ceased to be such.
In beginning of 1953, appellants went to Pakistan for temporary visit without passport; when wanting to return, compelled to obtain Pakistani passports.
Appellants obtained Pakistani passports only as device for securing return to India and compelled against their will; therefore did not acquire citizenship of Pakistan.
Appellants made efforts for cancellation of passports and permission to stay in India permanently but unsuccessful.
State of Madhya Pradesh served order dated November 11, 1955, under s. 3(2) of Foreigners Act, 1946, asking appellants to leave the country.
Appellants contend order illegal as they are not foreigners.
Appellants left India between March and May 1948; returned first time on temporary Pakistani passport in early part of 1955.
Permits granted to appellants to remain in India extended from time to time up to about October 1955; thereafter served with orders to quit India.
Appellants not citizens of India as voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship by obtaining passports from that country.
Suit dismissed by courts below as not maintainable in view of s.9(2) Citizenship Act.
Appeal by special leave from judgment dated January 23, 1960, of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No.473 of 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit filed by the appellants was properly dismissed on the ground that a civil court had no jurisdiction to entertain it, barred by s.9(2) of the Citizenship Act, 1955.
Whether appellants had ever acquired Indian citizenship, given migration to Pakistan in 1948, potentially under Art.7 of the Constitution.
Whether appellants, if Indian citizens, had acquired citizenship of Pakistan.

petitioner_arguments.text: Civil court's jurisdiction not barred as only when right created by statute and tribunal set up for determination of that right, jurisdiction taken away.
Appellants had no right to approach Central Government to decide if lost Indian citizenship, so right to civil court not barred.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sharafat Ali Khan v. State of U.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: Obtained Pakistani passports only as device to return to India, against will, did not acquire Pak citizenship.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship by obtaining passports; hence not Indian citizens.
Conceded position that civil court can decide if appellants ever Indian citizens; bar only under s.9 Citizenship Act for acquisition of foreign citizenship.

court_reasoning.text: s.9(2) Citizenship Act bars civil court jurisdiction only on question whether Indian citizen acquired citizenship of another country, when or how; to be determined by prescribed authority (Central Government per Rule 30).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bars only those specific questions; implies cannot be decided by anyone else.

court_reasoning.text: Suit raises whether appellants lost Indian citizenship by acquiring Pak citizenship (barred); but also whether they ever acquired Indian citizenship (migration 1948, Art.7 Const - not barred).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entire suit should not be dismissed; courts below erred.

court_reasoning.text: Court should decide if appellants Indian citizens on Jan 26, 1950; if no, dismiss suit; if yes, stay till Central Govt decides on foreign acquisition.
Rejects petitioner's contention that jurisdiction barred only for statutory rights with tribunal; competent legislature may take away jurisdiction otherwise.
No need to decide if appellants have right to approach Central Govt as AG concedes; view in Sharafat Ali Khan open to doubt.

holdings.text: s.9(2) Citizenship Act bars civil court from determining if Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship, when/how; such question for Central Government.
Civil court retains jurisdiction on whether person ever acquired Indian citizenship (e.g., under Art.7 due to 1948 migration).
If court finds never Indian citizens, dismiss suit; if were citizens, stay for Central Govt decision on foreign acquisition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sharafat Ali Khan v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied on by petitioner for no right to approach Central Govt so civil court jurisdiction not barred; court doubts view.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars civil court jurisdiction on whether, when, how person acquired foreign citizenship; to be decided by prescribed authority (Central Govt per Rule 30, Sch. III).

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Order served on appellants to leave India.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Migration to Pakistan in 1948 may mean never acquired Indian citizenship.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Central Government determines citizenship acquisition questions using specified evidence rules.

outcome.summary: Set aside orders and judgments of courts below; direct suit be heard and decided on all questions except whether appellants, having been Indian citizens, renounced and acquired foreign citizenship. If never citizens, dismiss; if were, stay till Central Govt decides.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand for partial hearing and stay on specific issue.

key_quotes.text: It seems to us clear that sub-sec. (2) of s. 9 of the Citizenship Act bars the jurisdiction of the civil court to try the question there mentioned because it says that those questions shall be determined by the prescribed authority which necessarily implies that it cannot be decided by anyone else.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on jurisdictional bar under s.9(2).

key_quotes.text: The only question, however, which a civil court is prevented by s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act from determining is the question whether a citizen of India has acquired citizenship of another country or when or how he acquired it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of bar, allowing other nationality questions.

key_quotes.text: The learned Attorney-General ... conceded this position.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Respondent concedes civil court role on non-barred issues.
